page.title: Las preguntas - Las frases interrogativas
page.introduction: Las preguntas que se contestan con información diferencian de preguntas sí/no en que contienen una palabra o una frase interrogativa, conocido como wh-phrases 'frases-wh' en inglés porque casi todos comienzan con las letras wh (who(m) 'quién', what 'qué', why 'por qué', where 'dónde', when 'cuándo', how 'cómo', which 'cuál', whose 'de quién'). En algunos idiomas, algunas o todas estas palabras interrogativas se expresan como afijos.

form.introduction: De los ejemplos de palabras interrogativas arriba, coloqúese lo más simplemente solamente como pronombres o adverbios, pero how 'cómo' puede estar un adverbio de la manera por sí mismo o una palabra del grado que modifica un adjetivo, como en how big 'cómo grande' o una palabra del grado que modifica un cuantificador, como en how many children 'cuántos niños'; what 'qué' puede ser un pronombre por sí mismo o un demostrativo modificando un sustantivo, como en what books 'qué libros'; which 'cuál' nunca se coloca solamente pero modifica siempre un sustantivo como demostrativo, como en which boy 'cuál muchacho'; y whose 'de quién puede ser un pronombre posesivo solo del soporte, o puede llenar la posición del poseedor en una frase nominal, como en whose toys 'de quién juguetes'.
form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark all of the interrogative words or affixes with the feature wh.
In addition, make sure that your word meaning 'which' either already has the category Dem or add the feature makeDem to the entry. In addition, since your language does not have any demonstratives, make sure that your word meaning 'which' either already has the category Art or add the feature makeArt to the entry. In addition, since your language does not have any demonstratives or articles, if you have a word meaning 'which', it will have to be treated as a possessor. As such, it simply acts as a pronoun like the majority of the interrogative words, and the category mapping will be handled by the Category Mapper at the end of this section. Add the case feature genitive to the entry to restrict its appearance to possessor position.absolutive to the entry to restrict the positions where it may appear.ergative to the entry to restrict the positions where it may appear.
The word meaning 'why' needs to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature reason.
The word meaning 'where' needs to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature locative.
The word meaning 'when' needs to have two entries, if it can be used as both an interrogative word and as a temporal adverb which can take a sentential complement. Both entries need to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature temporal. Add the feature wh to one entry and the features sentential embedded_IP to the other entry.
The word meaning 'how' needs to have two entries, one with the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner and another entry which can have any appropriate morphological category but has the features makeDeg modifies_Adj modifies_Q. The word meaning 'how' needs to have two entries, one with the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner and another entry which can have any appropriate morphological category but has the features makeDeg modifies_Q. The word meaning 'how' needs to have two entries, one with the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner and another entry which can have any appropriate morphological category but has the features makeDeg modifies_Adj. Since your language does not have stand alone degree words that modify quantifiers, you may have another interrogative word meaning 'how many' and/or 'how much'. These words/phrases act like quantifiers, so the entry needs to have the features makeQ wh. The word meaning 'how' needs to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner. Since your language does not have stand alone degree words that modify quantifiers, you may have another interrogative word meaning 'how many' and/or 'how much'. These words/phrases act like quantifiers, so the entry needs to have the features makeQ wh.
The word meaning 'what' also needs two entries if it can modify a noun as in English. This entry which allows it to modify a noun needs to have the category Dem or add the makeDem to the entry.
The normal pronoun use of the word meaning 'what' and the remainder of the interrogative words above need to be mapped to the category Pron. This will be handled by the Category Mapper at the end of this section.
The word meaning 'what' also needs two entries if it can modify a noun as in English. Since your language does not have any demonstratives, this entry which allows it to modify a noun needs to have the category Art or add the feature makeArt to the entry.
The normal pronoun use of the word meaning 'what' and the remainder of the interrogative words above need to be mapped to the category Pron. This will be handled by the Category Mapper at the end of this section.
Since your language does not have any demonstratives or articles, the word meaning 'what' only needs one entry. It simply acts as a pronoun like the majority of the interrogative words, and the category mapping to the category Pron will be handled by the Category Mapper at the end of this section. Do not add any case features to the entry, so it will be allowed in possessor position as well as taking the place of a full nominal phrase.
The word meaning 'whose' needs to have two entries, both with the category which will be mapped to the category Pron at the end of the section (and both with the feature wh). One entry needs the feature possessive for the stand alone case and the other entry needs the case feature genitive to restrict its appearance to possessor position.absolutive to restrict the positions where it may appear.ergative to restrict the positions where it may appear.

radioGroup.prompt: Su idioma permite demonstrativos de cualquier lado del sustantivo. ¿Dónde haga las palabras que significan 'cuál' y 'qué' ocurra?
radioGroup.radio: Siempre antes del sustantivo, incluso si otro determinador ocurre después del sustantivo
Siempre después del sustantivo, incluso si otro determinador ocurre antes del sustantivo
De cualquier lado, pero cuando hay un demostrativo en cada lado al mismo tiempo, ellos deben convenir en características (e.g. ambos sean palabras interrogativas o ambas no ser)
